trans-unit.source: Show chart with the history of your typing speed to see how you have been progressing over time.
This chart shows how your typing speed has been changing over time.
Please connect with Facebook or sign-up to enable this chart. Then we will be able to track your progress, high scores and share it with your friends.
Not enough data. You need to complete at least two exercises for chart to be shown.
You are not logged in. Chart is only available for registered users.
Practice typing custom text. Use this option if you think you are an advanced user and typing random text slows you down.

Typing accuracy is the number of typos you have made in the current exercise. Try to keep this number to a minimum. For novices it is important to develop typing accuracy first and only then typing speed.
Enable or disable highlighting of previously mistyped letters to see when mistakes are coming.

arse, arses, ass, asses, asshole, assholes, assholism, bang, banging, banger, bastard, bastards, bitch, bitches, bitching, bullshit, cock, cocks, crap, craps, craping, cunt, cunts, damn, dick, dicks, dickhead, dickheads, dike, filth, filths, fuck, fucks, fucking, fucker, f*ck, f*cks, f*cking, f*cker, motherfucker, motherfuckers, nigger, niggers, niggerz, paki, piss, pisses, pissing, pisser, poop, prick, pussy, shag, shit, shits, shity, slut, sluts, slag, twat, whore, whores
Top speed: {maxSpeed}, average speed: {avgSpeed} Today progress: {speedChange} Total time spent: {totalTime}
Thank you for evaluating keybr.com, the trial period is over. Please register or login to continue. Then you will be able to unlock extra features and track your learning progress day by day.
Please register or login to continue

Jabberwocky by Lewis Carroll >>> Twas brillig, and the slithy toves Did gyre and gimble in the wabe: All mimsy were the borogoves, And the mome raths outgrabe. >>> "Beware the Jabberwock, my son! The jaws that bite, the claws that catch! Beware the Jubjub bird, and shun The frumious Bandersnatch!" >>> He took his vorpal sword in hand: Long time the manxome foe he sought- So rested he by the Tumtum tree, And stood awhile in thought. >>> And, as in uffish thought he stood, The Jabberwock, with eyes of flame, Came whiffling through the tulgey wood, And burbled as it came! >>> One, two! One, two! And through and through The vorpal blade went snicker-snack! He left it dead, and with its head He went galumphing back. >>> "And hast thou slain the Jabberwock? Come to my arms, my beamish boy! O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!" He chortled in his joy. >>> 'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves Did gyre and gimble in the wabe: All mimsy were the borogoves, And the mome raths outgrabe."
Display map of the most pressed keys.
Switch to the preferred language and keyboard layout.
Error... Reload this page and try again.

Practice typing text generated from random letters. The advantage of this tutorial is that you can learn keyboard keys row by row. Start typing words composed from letters from the Caps Lock row, then include Tab and Shift rows.
If you want to type real words, provide your text to type out.
Choose keyboard layout specific to your language and country
Generate random text using letters from the Caps Lock row.
Generate random text using letters from the Caps Lock and Tab row.
Generate random text using letters from the Caps Lock, Tab and Shift row.
Generate random text using letter from the current level. In this mode you can learn keys row by row. Begin with Caps Lock row, then add Tab and Shift row.
Use content of a Blog/Web Feed as text source.

Typing speed measured in words per minute. A word is standardized to five characters or keystrokes. An average touch typist reaches 50 to 70 words per minute, while some positions can require 80 to 95. Some advanced typists work at speeds above 120.
Send your comments and suggestions to
This text is generated to teach touch typing. It contains characters from the current tutorial. Type this text using your keyboard. The board shows that you type correctly.

Switch to another tutorial. With each tutorial you learn additional keys, row by row. Start from the simplest tutorial and move on to the next tutorial when you feel proficient with the current one. Or provide your text to type out.
Use this virtual keyboard to find keys. Try not to look at the real keyboard. The next key is highlighted in green. When you miss a key it gets highlighted in red.
